etymologies: Old English æsce, aexe, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch as and German Asche

definitions: the powdery residue left after the burning of a substance

examples.text: a day's worth of paper burned to ashes

definitions: the remains of something destroyed; ruins

examples.text: the people are really living in the ashes of those traditions and institutions

definitions: the remains of the human body after cremation or burning

examples.text: his ashes were scattered on a Welsh mountainside

definitions: powdery material thrown out by a volcano

examples.text: the plains have been showered by volcanic ash

shortDefinitions: powdery material thrown out by volcano

definitions: the mineral component of an organic substance, as assessed from the residue left after burning

examples.text: coal contains higher levels of ash than premium fuels

phrases.text: turn to ashes in one's mouth

etymologies: Old English æsc, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch es and German Esche

definitions: a tree with silver-gray bark and compound leaves. The ash is widely distributed throughout north temperate regions where it can form forests.

notes.text: Genus Fraxinus, family Oleaceae: many species, including the North American white ash (F. americana) and the European ash (F. excelsior)

definitions: the hard pale wood of the ash tree.
any of a number of unrelated trees with leaves similar to the ash.
an Old English runic letter, ᚫ, a vowel intermediate between a and e. It is represented in the Roman alphabet by the symbol æ or Æ.
etymologies: so named from the word of which it was the first letter
